item.title: A Strange and Messy Deliverance
item.description:
The only constraints on this sermon were that it be between 15 and 25 minutes long, and be on a text from the Old Testament. Video and its audio are from an old MacBook Pro pointed at the podium. Dedicated audio is from my iPhone in my shirt pocket.

Audio

Download

Video

A Strange and Messy Deliverance (Judges 3:7â€“31) from Chris Krycho on Vimeo.

Prayer

Let us pray. Gracious Father: thank you for revealing yourself to us, especially in your Son, our Lord; and for filling us with your Spirit so that we may know you truly. As we come to your word tonight, help us know you more deeply and worship you more faithfully. In Christâ€™s name, amen.

Introduction

Please open your Bibles to Judges, chapter 3. And as you turn there, I want you to think about these words:

Boring exegesis must be wrong when the texts are so obviously full of life.

Again:

Boring exegesis must be wrong when the texts are so obviously full of life.

Thatâ€™s N. T. Wright, speaking of the Pauline epistles. But I think, equally applicable whenever we come to Godâ€™s wordâ€”especially in preaching and teachingâ€”and most especially when the texts are like this one: lively, to say the least; strange, even.

I have two goals for this sermon. The firstâ€”always the firstâ€”is to show the grace of God clearly. As Bryan Chappell, the author Christ-Centered Preaching, puts it, we want to see how God did for his people then what they could not do for themselves; and through that to be be reminded of what he has done for us, that we could not do for ourselves. Thatâ€™s the point of this sermon: Godâ€™s grace in Christ.

But secondarilyâ€”thinking about boring exegesis; thinking about hard texts like Judges 3â€”I hope to encourage you that these texts, these strange texts, these sometimes difficult textsâ€”theyâ€™re for us, and for our good. Theyâ€™re for our people, and our peopleâ€™s good. We donâ€™t need to ashamed of them, or embarrassed by them, or intimidated by them. Rather, we can come away seeing how these texts magnify the grace of God, how these texts remind us to look to Christ.

Body

Othniel: The first judge

So letâ€™s look and see. This is a long passage, with three judgesâ€”Othniel, Ehud, and Shamgarâ€”so weâ€™ll take each in turn. Read with me, starting in verse 7:

And the people of Israel did what was evil in the sight of the LORD. They forgot the LORD their God and served the Baals and the Asheroth. Therefore the anger of the LORD was kindled against Israel, and he sold them into the hand of Cushan-rishathaim king of Mesopotamia. And the people of Israel served Cushan-rishathaim eight years. But when the people of Israel cried out to the LORD, the LORD raised up a deliverer for the people of Israel, who saved them, Othniel the son of Kenaz, Calebâ€™s younger brother. The Spirit of the LORD was upon him, and he judged Israel. He went out to war, and the LORD gave Cushan-rishathaim king of Mesopotamia into his hand. And his hand prevailed over Cushan-rishathaim. So the land had rest forty years. Then Othniel the son of Kenaz died.

This first narrative is probably the easiest to understand. Othniel is the first judge. He is the prototype for all the other judges that follow. His story shows out the pattern for the whole book, the same one the author laid out back in chapter 2: sin, discipline, a cry for mercy, and Godâ€™s deliverance through a judge.

Verse 7: Israel sins. They forgot Yahweh their God. They served the Baâ€™als and the Asheroth instead of the God who had delivered them from Egypt.

Thatâ€™s an interesting word choice: forgotâ€”and itâ€™s an important word, not only in this passage, but throughout the Bible. After all the reminders in the covenant: Set up these stones so you remember! Teach your children, so they remember. Bind it on your hands and your forehead, so you remember! And they forgot.

Othniel is Calebâ€™s brother, note. They forgot in the first generation they were in the land.

When we forget, we get things wrong. Youâ€™ve seen it happen: a spouse forgets an anniversary, and spends some time â€œin the dog house.â€ Or parents who miss a school event for their children, and leave them feeling like they donâ€™t matter. Forgetting a friendâ€™s birthday: maybe youâ€™re not as close as you thought.

And sometimesâ€¦ we all forget who God is, what he has done for us, and what our relationship to him is as the covenant people of God. We find ourselves fixated on the approval of the people in the pews, on the applause of subscribers to our popular podcast, on the affirmation of our professional peers. We become idolatersâ€”just like Israel.

But he showed them mercy. How? â€œHe sold them into the hand of Cushan-rishathaim, king of Mesopotamiaâ€â€”not mercy the way we might be inclined to think of it, but real, deep mercy.

Because: see what happens? It had the intended effect. They remembered Yahweh and called out to him. And he delivered themâ€”both from the pagan King, and from their idolatry, at least for a time! The Spirit came on Othniel, and he led Israel to war, and God delivered them from Cushan-rishathaim, and they had peace for forty years.

God delivered his people, and Othniel, this first judge, was a good judge. He wasnâ€™t a prophet like Moses; he didnâ€™t give them lasting rest, any more than Joshua had (40 years is good, but itâ€™s not forever); and he didnâ€™t circumcise their hearts. Not the judge then. A good judge, but not the judge.

Ehud: The assassin

Sadly, he was also the best of the Judges. Things only go downhill from here. Whoâ€™s next? Ehud: the assassin. Letâ€™s read again, picking up in verse 12:

And the people of Israel again did what was evil in the sight of the LORD, and the LORD strengthened Eglon the king of Moab against Israel, because they had done what was evil in the sight of the LORD. He gathered to himself the Ammonites and the Amalekites, and went and defeated Israel. And they took possession of the city of palms. And the people of Israel served Eglon the king of Moab eighteen years.

Then the people of Israel cried out to the LORD, and the LORD raised up for them a deliverer, Ehud, the son of Gera, the Benjaminite, a left-handed man. The people of Israel sent tribute by him to Eglon the king of Moab. And Ehud made for himself a sword with two edges, a cubit in length, and he bound it on his right thigh under his clothes. And he presented the tribute to Eglon king of Moab. Now Eglon was a very fat man. And when Ehud had finished presenting the tribute, he sent away the people who carried the tribute. But he himself turned back at the idols near Gilgal and said, â€œI have a secret message for you, O king.â€ And he commanded, â€œSilence.â€ And all his attendants went out from his presence. And Ehud came to him as he was sitting alone in his cool roof chamber. And Ehud said, â€œI have a message from God for you.â€ And he arose from his seat. And Ehud reached with his left hand, took the sword from his right thigh, and thrust it into his belly. And the hilt also went in after the blade, and the fat closed over the blade, for he did not pull the sword out of his belly; and the dung came out. Then Ehud went out into the porch and closed the doors of the roof chamber behind him and locked them. When he had gone, the servants came, and when they saw that the doors of the roof chamber were locked, they thought, â€œSurely he is relieving himself in the closet of the cool chamber.â€ And they waited till they were embarrassed. But when he still did not open the doors of the roof chamber, they took the key and opened them, and there lay their lord dead on the floor.

Ehud escaped while they delayed, and he passed beyond the idols and escaped to Seirah. When he arrived, he sounded the trumpet in the hill country of Ephraim. Then the people of Israel went down with him from the hill country, and he was their leader. And he said to them, â€œFollow after me, for the LORD has given your enemies the Moabites into your hand.â€ So they went down after him and seized the fords of the Jordan against the Moabites and did not allow anyone to pass over. And they killed at that time about 10,000 of the Moabites, all strong, able-bodied men; not a man escaped. So Moab was subdued that day under the hand of Israel. And the land had rest for eighty years.

We see the same pattern again hereâ€¦ sort of. We see Israel sin, and God discipline them. And we see Israel cry out to their covenant God, and we see him deliver them.

But of course, Ehudâ€™s story is more complicated than Othnielâ€™s was. Some of the details here might initially perplex us. Why do we hear about how fat the king is? Why do we hear about the dung coming out after he gets stabbed? Why almost any of the extraneous-seeming details in this story?

Well, this is satire. (Which doesnâ€™t make it untrue, of course.) The author plays up the ridiculous elements in this bit of history to make a point.

What do we see here?

A conquering king! â€¦

  • whoâ€™s actually morbidly obese, not exactly a strapping warrior
  • who, so cunning he could forge an alliance with the Ammonites and Amalekites, gets fooled by a simple trick (â€œOh king, I have secret message for youâ€)â€”heâ€™s either hopelessly naive or profoundly overconfident; neither is good
  • a man who so comically out of line with what a king should be that his servants donâ€™t even notice when thereâ€™s a wretched stench and he takes a looong time relieving himself

Great king.

And his servants? They arenâ€™t exactly top-drawer. They donâ€™t even notice Ehud escaping after he assassinated their kingâ€¦

If we read the story right, itâ€™s humorous. The author is poking fun at the Moabites! â€œThose Moabites!â€

Right?

But, waitâ€¦ those Moabites conquered Israel. This ridiculous Moabite king?â€¦ Ehud was there to bring him tribute.

Israel is the real joke. The idolaters who got conquered by this king. Ouch.

This is what good satire does. It sneaks in, makes you laugh, and then hits you where it counts.

And what about Ehud himself? What about this savior figure? Heâ€™s not good either. Heâ€™s a vicious assassin, a traitor who stabbed the man he was legally supposed to be serving.

This story is messy. Not just because of the dung coming out. But because while yes, God did deliver his people, and that is goodâ€”but Ehud isnâ€™t the kind of deliverer we want, not the kind of deliverer we need.

Not the brutal killer, but the one who was brutally killed.

Not the one who defeated a foreign king by stabbing him in the gut, but the one who overcame both the pagan oppressor and the idolatry that led to that oppression by being stabbed, by taking the weapon to his gut.

The book of Judges shows us over and over again what weâ€™re like left to our own purposes. How even our human saviors are woefully insufficient. The covenant hope, proclaimed from the start of Genesis and made so clear in Deuteronomyâ€¦ was still waiting to be fulfilled.

Shamgar & Unifying Theme

And then we come to the end of this chapterâ€”to Shamgar: the man with an ox-goad and his one verse: verse 31.

After him was Shamgar the son of Anath, who killed 600 of the Philistines with an oxgoad, and he also saved Israel.

So if youâ€™re like me, youâ€™re wondering at least two things about this passage. One is: what in the world is an oxgoad? Thatâ€™s the easy one: Itâ€™s a cattle prod. A long wooden pole with a point on the end. Makes for a decent improvised spear.

But the other question, the bigger question, is why does Ehud get paragraphs, with lurid details for a satireâ€¦ and Shamgar gets just one sentence?

We have a man who, based on his name, doesnâ€™t even seem to be an Israelity, who shows up, kills 600 Philistines with an ox-goad, and then heâ€™s gone. He gets one mention in Deborahâ€™s song in chapter 5, but basically, this is it.

So why mention him at all if heâ€™s so seemingly unimportant? Why these proportions?

After all, this is the inspired word of God. And the author had a reason for giving us these stories, even these proportions. Heâ€™s making a point.

We read this and I, for one, think, â€œOh, that sounds interesting; how did he do that with a cattle prâ€”â€ â€œNO. Thatâ€™s not the question.â€ He slams the door on that question.

Shamgarâ€™s skill with an ox-goad is not the point, any more than Ehudâ€™s skill as an assassin was the point, any more even than Othnielâ€™s skill as a military leadership was the point. No more, I put it to you, than any of us are the point.

â€œAnd he also saved Israel.â€ Those words tell us what we need to know. Who saved Israel? Shamgarâ€¦ Ehudâ€¦ Othnielâ€¦ but really, in every case, Yahweh. The covenant-keeping God, who saved Israel not only from 600 Philistines, not only from a Moabite king worthy of derision, not only from a mighty king of Mesopotamiaâ€”but from her idolatry.

Summary and Exhortation

Somedayâ€”someday, after many judges, many kings, many priests, many prophetsâ€”there would come a delivererâ€”a judge, a prophet, a priest, a kingâ€”

  • who would give the land rest, who would give the people of God true rest, for more than just a generation; foreverâ€¦
  • who would be a wise king
  • who would be gentle and gracious ruler
  • who would give Godâ€™s people circumcised hearts
  • who would fulfill the covenant hopes and take on himself the covenant curses of Deuteronony, of Exodus, of Genesis

We have that deliverer. We have Christ. â€œAnd he also saved Israel.â€ So when we read, when we teach, when we preach, let us look, every time, and see what God did for his people that they could not do for themselves. Let us, in every passage, in every picture of grace, find a reminder of what God has done for us in Christ, that we could not do for ourselves.

We have a deliverer. Donâ€™t forget. Donâ€™t let your people forget. We have a deliverer.

Gracious Father: thank you for delivering us. Help us be faithful with your word. Help us remember, and help us remind your people, of how you have delivered us. In the name of Jesus, our savior, amen.

item.title: A Humble, Selfless, Unity
item.description:
The only constraints on this sermon were that it be between 15 and 25 minutes long, and be on a text from an epistle. Video is from an old MacBook Pro pointed at the podium.

Audio

Download

Video

A Humble, Selfless Unity (Philippians 2:1â€“11) from Chris Krycho on Vimeo.

Good evening. Letâ€™s pray before we begin.

Gracious God, may your word be clear in our hearts. May your Spirit open our minds to see you more clearly and love as you have loved us. May we see you, and may I not obscure you. Thank you for revealing yourself to us.

Introduction

Our text for this evening is Philippians 2:1â€“11. It might be a familiar passage to many of you, but I think it might also be a surprising passage to you. It was for me.

I donâ€™t know if youâ€™ve ever been walking along someplace familiar and had something prompt you to stop and notice something about your surroundings that you had never seen before. Maybe you went back to the house you grew up in, and the house is the same, but you arenâ€™tâ€”and you notice the little cracks in the ceiling. Were those always there? You look at the wall in your older sisterâ€™s bedroom. Was it always that color? I thought it was lighter than that. You go down the stairs into the basement, and â€œYup, they always creaked like that,â€ your mother tells you. You start to ask about the way the basement smells and she just shakes her head at you.

It had been a while since I read this passage, and it kind of felt like thinking you had grown up in a really nice house and going back and discovering that it was mansion. But whether youâ€™ve read this passage a hundred times, or this your first time opening a Bible, God is inviting us into a beautiful mansion tonight.

1. Believers called to humble, selfless, unity (2:1â€“5)

As we come to Philippians 2, Paul has just spent the first chunk of a letter to these Christians in Philippiâ€”good friends to him, people who have supported his ministryâ€”about his circumstancesâ€¦ which arenâ€™t great, frankly. He wrote this letter from prison. But, one way or another, he has seen a great many people hear the good news about Jesus as a result of his in prison. But he also knows that the Philippians are having a hard time, and he knows that they need encouragement in their faith. He knew that when things get hardâ€”whether thatâ€™s persecution, physical or mental illness, death among your friends or family, losing jobsâ€”when life gets hard, we can turn on each other. And Paul called the Philippians, in the midst of their trialsâ€”God is calling us, tonight, in the midst of our trialsâ€”to something different: to a humble, selfless, unity.

Letâ€™s read:

1So if there is any encouragement in Christ, any comfort from love, any participation in the Spirit, any affection and sympathy, 2complete my joy by being of the same mind, having the same love, being in full accord and of one mind.

Four reasons

Paul opens with four reasons for people to live with this humble, selfless unity. â€œIf there is anyâ€¦â€

  1. encouragement in Christ
  2. comfort from love
  3. participation in [which could also read fellowship in or with] the Spirit
  4. affection and sympathy

â€œIf there is any,â€ he says. Is there any? Well, yes. There is encouragement in Christ. We do find comfort from being loved, by God and by each other. As believers, we do have fellowship with the Spirit, and through him with Christ and the Father, and of course with each other too. We do have God-given affection and sympathy for each other, and even for non-believers.

In other words, Paul is using that â€œifâ€ to quietly point the Philippian believers to a reality. When he asks them to complete his joy if these things are true, heâ€™s saying, â€œLook, these four things are true.â€ You do encouragement; comfort; fellowship; affection and sympathy. And just as they did, so do we.

So given those four good reasons, Paul asks them to complete his joy. As he has told them already, earlier in the epistle, he already has great joyâ€”in seeing the gospel go forth. He even rejoices when people preach the gospel in an attempt to make him jealous. But his joy isnâ€™t complete without something else. If these four reasons are the foundation for that completion, the finished building is humble, selfless, unity. But what we might ask: what is the structure of that finished building?

Three ways

There are three. Four foundation stones, and three pillars on that base. Paul told his friends they would complete his joyâ€”they would fill it upâ€”by:

  1. being of the same mind
  2. having the same love
  3. being in full accord and of one mind

(If youâ€™re worried about my counting: affection and sympathy go together, and so do â€œbeing in full accord and of one mind.â€ If you have true affection for someone, you will feel sympathy for her when she is struggling. If youâ€™re in full accord with someone, itâ€™s like you and he share a mind. So: four foundation stones, and these three pillars.)

And what we see in these three pillars is that these three ways are really one way. Theyâ€™re one structure. And that one way, is to be one. That one way is unity. Joy, for the apostle, and I think it is fair to say Godâ€™s joy in our fellowship, is complete when we are truly unified. Not identical, but unified.

But how? How do we have the same mind? How do we have the same love? How can we be in full accord and of one mind? That seems rather abstract. If I sat down my three-and-a-half year old and my 20-month old and said, â€œOkay, Ellie and Kate, you need to have unity between you two,â€ they would just stare at me. Ellie, the older one, might say, â€œYes, daddy!â€ just to be good, but they wouldnâ€™t know what to do with it. Kate, the younger one, would probably yell â€œNo!â€ because sheâ€™s a toddler and weâ€™re working on that right now. And wherever you are: whether youâ€™re saying, â€œOkayâ€¦â€ but you donâ€™t really get it, or youâ€™re saying â€œNo, no way! Have you met these people?â€ Paul draws us forward. He gives us some help, makes it a little more concrete.

Two contrasts

Paul gives us two pairs of contrasts to help us see a little more clearly what this kind of unity looks like. Capstones to match the foundation, if you will.

3Do nothing [, he says in v. 3,] from selfish ambition or conceit, but in humility count others more significant than yourselves.

Thatâ€™s the first capstone, the first contrast. Not selfish ambition, not conceit, but humility, and counting others more important than yourself. So we see first that this unity is humble unity. It comes becomes Iâ€™m valuing you above me. Iâ€™m not trying to exalt myself. Iâ€™m thinking of how I can make you do well instead.

Verse 4 shows us the second contrast, the second capstone:

4Let each of you look not only to his own interests, but also to the interests of others.

This unity, then, is also selfless. When weâ€™re healthy, we donâ€™t just aim to get our own. â€œLooking out for number one!â€ No, instead, we help others accomplish their hopes. We give of our time; our money; our sleep; our space â€“ to help others.

So this is the church. This is the kind of building weâ€™re supposed to be. As Paul puts it in Ephesians, weâ€™re being built together into a temple for Godâ€”a temple of people known for their humble, selfless, unityâ€”their love.

We have these four foundations: encouragement in Christ, comfort from love, fellowship with the Spirit, and affection and sympathy. We have three pillars of unity: being of the same mind, having the same love, being in full accord and of one mind. We have two capstones: calls to humility and selflessness.

But you might be asking now, â€œHow? I want that unity; I even want to be selfless and humble, even if that sounds kind of hard. But I donâ€™t know how.â€ And to that, Paul says, â€œDonâ€™t worry; Iâ€™ll give you an example. In fact, here is the example.â€ And he shows us Christâ€”verse 5: â€œHave this mind among yourselves, which was also in Christ Jesusâ€¦â€

2. The foundation of humble, selfless, unity (2:6â€“11)

The mind of Christ! Thatâ€™s a heady thing to think about. But for Paul, itâ€™s deeply practical, in fact. He gives us a very succinct summary of Jesusâ€™ ministry. And what was Jesus like? He was humble. He was selfless. (And if youâ€™re thinking, â€œBut what about unity?â€ youâ€™re right. Hold on to that thought. Weâ€™ll come back to it.) Letâ€™s start by looking at Christâ€™s example.

Christ humbled himself

6who [Christ Jesus], though he was in the form of God, did not count equality with God a thing to be grasped [â€”something to be held ontoâ€”], 7but emptied himself, by taking the form of a servant, being born in the likeness of men. 8And being found in human form, he humbled himself by becoming obedient to the point of death, even death on a cross.

What we see here is one of the great mysteries our faith. God became man. We could take a dozen sermons on this point alone. But Paul has something very specific for us to see from the Incarnation here. Whatever prerogatives we might haveâ€”whatever money, whatever fame, whatever position or statusâ€”the Son had more. And Jesus Christ lived as a servant. He didnâ€™t hold onto what was his (and it really was his, by right!). He came as one of us. When you read here, â€œin the likeness of man,â€ donâ€™t think â€œhe was kind of like us.â€ Hebrews tells us that he was exactly was we areâ€”yet without sin.

And that degradation goes down and down and down. He became a baby, who needed to be changed. He dealt, like my older daughter does, with younger siblings who tormented him. He was teased by other children. He went through puberty and had his voice go all scratchy. He worked for many years in obscurity. When he started his ministry, he was rejected as often as accepted, loved for his miracles and not for the God he revealed, mocked even by his own family, and wandered around without a home. Remember, the God of all the universe. And ultimately, he died. Died a sinnerâ€™s shameful death. He took our humiliation. And through all of it, he did not complain, he just served. So Christ is our model.

A convicting model, at least for me. Jesus, the real flesh-and-blood Jesus who was tempted just like us, is the perfect man. He is what it means to be human rightly. And he served. Heâ€™s the rightful king! And he served. Do I serve like that? Do you? Or do we demand our rights?

The Father exalted Christ

Now, as we come into these final verses, we see what at first might seem like a bit of a strange turn. Paul is trying to teach us about this kind of humble, selflessness,â€”and yes, unity. Hmm. And we were tracking along, as we saw the concrete example of Jesus living and dying selflessly. Feeling conviction, even; I certainly was and am. But then we get to this:

9Therefore God has highly exalted him and bestowed on him the name that is above every name, 10so that at the name of Jesus every knee should bow, in heaven and on earth and under the earth, 11and every tongue confess that Jesus Christ is Lord, to the glory of God the Father.

This is, at first blush, a bit of a challenge. â€œOkay. I mean, itâ€™s good that Jesus is exalted. But how does it fit? Am I going to be exalted? Am I supposed to serve because Jesus was exalted? Whatâ€™s going on here?â€

There are two parts to this. One of them is, yes, that Jesus is Lord. We are citizens of his kingdom, and if his people lived like that, his people should certainly live like that. So that is one part of it.

But there is something else going on here, too.

And thisâ€”oh, this! What do we see here? We see the Father exalting the son. He highly exalted him. He gave him the name that is above every other name. The Father wants every one to say, â€œJesus is Lord!â€ The Father wants everyone to bow down and worship Jesus. And Jesus, the Sonâ€”heâ€™s doing all of this, heâ€™s becoming a servant, taking on human nature, dying, on a cross to what end? To the glory of the Father!

We have a little glimpse here into somethingâ€¦ awesome. We see the Father, saying to the Son, â€œLet me exalt you!â€ And Jesus says to the Father, â€œAll the glory is yours!â€ And the Father to the Son, and the Son to the Father, back and forth, and back and forth, forever. This is the life of the trinity. This is the eternal life of the triune God: humble, selfless, unity! Love!

And this is what weâ€™re meant to be. This is what the church is for. This is what humanity is for: men and women made in the image of Godâ€”humble, selfless, unity.

The life of the Trinity, in the life of the church. This is the building weâ€™re meant to be. This is the temple. This is the mansion.

Paul has taken our question: â€œHow do I live like that?â€ and heâ€™s answered it by showing us how the life of the triune God took on flesh, and lived among us. Was our servant. Died for us. He says: â€œHow Christ lived is how we are meant to live.â€ And he reminds us, back there in v. 1: â€œIf there is any encouragement in Christ, any comfort from love, any participation in the Spiritâ€”any fellowship with the Spirit, remember; any affection and sympathy, complete my joyâ€¦â€ We have fellowship with the Spirit. Thatâ€™s where our unity comes from: not common interests, not shared experiences, not being the same age, or sex, or ethnicity, or social standing, or economic status.

Weâ€™re meant to be a little picture, every day, of the Trinity. And the way we do that, is by living like Christ did. We choose, every day, to serve the people around us, instead of ourselves. We choose, every day, not to put ourselves first, but to put others first. We choose, every day, not to make ourselves look great, but to love others.

Exhortation

Brothers and sisters, here is my challenge to you today. Fill up your joy, and fill up my joy, and fill out our Triune Godâ€™s joy in you!â€”by loving one another as he has loved us. This kind of humble, selfless, unity is not a burden. It is what we are for. And yes, in this fallen world, it is hard sometimes. But we have the Spirit. We participate in Godâ€™s own love. Mysteryâ€” awesome mystery! Let us love one another. Let us count one another more important than ourselves. Let us look not only to our own interests, but to each otherâ€™s. Let us live in the humble, selfless, unity of our Kingâ€™s kingdom.

And friend, if you are not a believer, and you look at this picture, I hope youâ€™re thinking, â€œYes. Thatâ€™s what the world ought to look like.â€ Because it is. And itâ€™s beautiful. Weâ€™re not meant not for self-absorption. Weâ€™re meant to live like Christ did. So I challenge you: call Christ lord. Let his death be yours, and his resurrection, tooâ€”come walk after him with us.

Let us pray to our loving, selfless, humble God of unity.

God we praise you, who are love and light forever. Thank you for your loveâ€”for sharing it with us, humbly and selflessly; for drawing us into your love and restoring us to what you designed us for. Thank you for building us into a temple for your Spirit. Help us walk in this same humble, selfless unity.

item.title: Power and Mercy
item.description:
The Bible exposition class for which I prepared this sermon involves writing but not delivering a sermon. If, at some point in the future, I actually deliver this sermon (e.g.Â in my sermon delivery course next semester), I will update this post with a link to the audio and/or video.

Introduction

Recent estimates suggest that the United States of America currently spends about three times as much money on our military as the next biggest military spender out there, China. In fact, if you add up the military spending of China, Russia, Saudi Arabia, France, Great Britain, India, and Germany, we still spend more. And remember, Chinaâ€™s and Indiaâ€™s populations are both over four times larger than ours. Whatâ€™s more, corruption and graft notwithstanding, our military-industrial complex is incredibly advanced. Itâ€™s fair to say that America has the most powerful, best equipped, most effective military apparatus in the whole world.

And yet. And yet, as a country, we are very afraid. All of that power canâ€™t protect us from everything. And we are very feared. For all of Americaâ€™s lofty ideals, we have made a mess of things pretty often. Weâ€™ve gotten it wrong. Having power, it turns out, isnâ€™t enough. Having enough power matters, but so does having the right kind of power, and so does how you use that power.

As we look at Mark 5:1â€“20, weâ€™re going to see that play out. Itâ€™s not just having power that matters. It matters who has the power, and how they use it. Do they torment? Or do they show mercy?

Iâ€™ll give you a hint: we want power coupled with mercy. You can see, if you look at verse 19, how this whole passage hinges on that. When all is said and done, the man in the middle of this story gets to go tell all his friends and neighbors how much the Lord had done for himâ€”how powerful God isâ€”and how the Lord had shown him mercy.

Exposition

Context

So letâ€™s see how Mark gets us there. As we come to our text, we read: â€œThey came to the other side of the sea, to the country of the Gerasenes.â€

â€œThe other side of the sea from what?â€ you might be asking. Well, from Galilee, where Jesus had been teaching. Back at the beginning of chapter 4, Mark tells us about a series of parables that Jesus taught about his new kingdom. And those parables particularly emphasized peopleâ€™s response as his kingdom comes. Some reject it entirely; some look excited about it at first, but ultimately arenâ€™t a part of it; and some, a few, really are citizens of the new kingdom.

Then, back in 4:35, Mark switched to a series of narrativesâ€”four stories. This is Markâ€™s basic strategy: tell us what Jesus said, and then show us what he did. Why? Well, because the parables werenâ€™t just cryptic things Jesus said to confuse people; he was telling his disciples, the ones who had ears to hear, how things really were. Each thing Jesus did showed that what he said was true.

His kingdom wasnâ€™t coming the way people thought, or even to the people who thought it was for them. And he wasnâ€™t the kind of king they had in mind, either. He had authority not just over nations and troops, but (as Mark shows us in these four stories), over the sea and the sky, over demonsâ€”thatâ€™s todayâ€™s passageâ€”over incurable illness, even over death. And in each of these events, we see that Jesus wasnâ€™t just a powerful king. He was also a merciful king.

Now, within these four narratives, Mark breaks things down into two pairs of miracle stories which hang together: the storm and the demonized man, and the two healings back on the other side of the sea. Today, we find ourselves in the second half of that first pair. With the storm, the disciples could not save themselves, so Jesus rebuked the storm, and there was a great calm, and the disciples were afraid. We are going to see those same ideas here: someone who cannot save himself, Jesus rebuking something, a great calm as a result, and people being afraid. We will see Jesusâ€™ power and mercy. And we will see a different response than fearâ€”a better one.

Beat 1: A wild man â€“ 5:1â€“6

So letâ€™s follow Mark on this journey. Verse 2 tells us that â€œwhen Jesus had stepped out of the boat, immediately there met him out of the tombs a man with an unclean spiritâ€. Verse 6 reiterates the pointâ€”â€œAnd when he saw Jesus from afar, he ran and fell down before himâ€â€”but first Mark wants us to know something about who this man was. Verses 3 through 5 tell us:

He lived among the tombs. And no one could bind him anymore, not even with a chain, for he had often been bound with shackles and chains, but he wrenched the chains apart, and he broke the shackles in pieces. No one had the strength to subdue him. Night and day among the tombs and on the mountains he was always crying out and cutting himself with stones.

In other words, this was not a man in need of a little help, an appointment with a counselor. No, here we have a man enslaved. Nothing anyone could do would help him.

What we have here is Mark establishing both the characters involved, and the â€œpower curveâ€ for the rest of the scene. If youâ€™re reading a superhero comic or watching a superhero movie, you have a sense of how strong everyone is. And of course, this leads to all sorts of conundrums. Who would win in a fight? Next yearâ€™s Batman vs.Â Superman: Dawn of Justice and Captain America: Civil War both hinge on this. Who is stronger? Who will win? And of course, if you let the wrong characters in, the game just becomes pointless. I saw an interview with the writers behind Captain America, where they explained why the Hulk wouldnâ€™t be in the movie. You add in the Hulk, and itâ€™s game over for the other team. Thereâ€™s no tension in the conflict anymore. The Hulk just wins.

And thatâ€™s basically the picture Mark shows us in this passage. Itâ€™s pretty clear: the demons were stronger. Nothing anyone could do was effective. They couldnâ€™t even keep this man imprisoned; verse 4 has him acting like, well, like the Hulk. They tried chaining him up hand and foot; he just ripped the chains on his wrists off and smashed the fetters on his feet. â€œNo one,â€ Mark says, â€œhad the strength to subdue him.â€ Healing him was out of the question. And the man himself was clearly totally under the demonsâ€™ control. The â€œsuper-villainsâ€ had the upper hand.

Now, the Hulk can be kind of fun to watch, but thatâ€™s not what we have here. They made a mockery of this man. We shouldnâ€™t take that lightly. They made him run around screaming, naked, cutting himself, in the midst of the tombs. There is a reason Mark describes him as having an unclean spirit. The demons were doing everything in their powerâ€”short of killing this manâ€”to defile what God had called â€œvery goodâ€ and what he had promised to redeem: his humanity.

So thereâ€™s the power curve when Jesus arrives on the scene; there are the characters. As soon as Jesus gets off the boat, this man comes out to meet him. And then, perhaps surprisingly, given that power curveâ€”but then again, maybe not so surprising given what Jesus has already done in this gospelâ€”verse 6 tells us that the man falls down at his knees before Jesus. He goes prostrate. Flat on his face. The way you would kneel before someone absolutely more powerful than you. Jesusâ€™ arrival is clearly a change from the status quo.

Beat 2: A merciful act â€“ 5:7â€“13

Setup

So Mark has set the scene for us: here is a man who has been tormented for who knows how long, and as soon Jesus steps off the boat, he man comes running up and throws himself down at Jesusâ€™ feet. Thatâ€™s quite the welcoming party. Put yourself in the disciplesâ€™ shoes for a moment. Youâ€™ve just seen Jesus go from sleeping in the back of a boatâ€”in the middle of the kind of storm that scared the Galilean fishermen who are with youâ€”to standing up and telling a storm to be quiet and it does. Youâ€™re afraid. And then you get to the other side, still more than a little in shock from that, and a naked man with cuts all over his body comes up to Jesus and throws himself at his feet and starts arguing with him, shouting at him. You might be afraid all over again. And for good reason. Notice that throughout the whole passage, the disciples are just onlookers. This is out of their league, too; so they just watch.

Beat 2a: Jesusâ€™ power â€“ 5:7â€“10

Dealing with the man and his impure spirit is not, however, out of Jesusâ€™ league. Verses 7â€“10 make it very clear that Jesus is absolutely and unquestionably the most powerful person in this encounter.

Notice, too, that the demonized man is arguing with Jesus because Jesus is arguing with him. Verses 7 and 8 tell us:

He shouted at the top of his voice, â€œWhat do you want with me, Jesus, Son of the Most High God? In Godâ€™s name donâ€™t torture me!â€ For Jesus had said to him, â€œCome out of this man, you impure spirit!â€

Jesus picked this fight, and itâ€™s not going to go down well for the demons.

Now we know from ancient records that there were both Greek and Jewish exorcists who made it their business to drive out evil spirits. You will find the same in many non-Western cultures today, andâ€”as an asideâ€”I think those cultures probably have the right of it more than we do. It has been said that the greatest trick the devil ever pulled was convincing people he didnâ€™t exist, and that seems about right. How can you possibly fight something you donâ€™t even believe exists? Itâ€™s a brilliant, devious strategic move. You can pull the North Korea strategyâ€”try to constantly rattle your saber to keep everyone afraid of you. Or you can act like an assassin: keep a low profile, and if possible donâ€™t even let your would-be opponents know you exist, until youâ€™ve killed them and caused mayhem. In the hyper-secular West, that seems to be the satanic strategy of the hour, and I think itâ€™s fair to say itâ€™s been reasonably successful for our enemyâ€”even if we know from passages like this one that Jesusâ€™ ultimate victory is guaranteed.

That wasnâ€™t the strategy of the day back then, though. And we know from those old records that the general strategy for dealing with demons was to try to use powerful command words and phrases, or to negotiate and bargain, or to use the demonâ€™s name to get spiritual power over them, or to try to use other divine powers to bind them.

But we donâ€™t see any of that in this passage. The demons recognize Jesusâ€™ power and authority right away. You can see it there in verse 7: as soon as Jesus tells them to leave, they plead with him not to torment them. And you donâ€™t plead with someone not to torment you unless they can torment you. By the time Jesus asks for a name in verse 9, the demons have already acknowledged Jesusâ€™ power and authority in the situation. Whatâ€™s more, they call him â€œSon of the Most High Godâ€ there in verse 7. Now, this title does double duty here.

First, it is another confirmation of Markâ€™s claim throughout his gospel: that Jesus is in fact the Son of God. And significantly, the early confessions to that effect all come on the lips of demons he exorcises. The spiritual forces know spiritual authority when they see it, even if the people donâ€™t see it yet. So confirming that Jesus is â€œthe Son of Godâ€ is the first thing this does.

The second thing it does is establish that Jesus isnâ€™t just another player in the spiritual game. Whatever other gods someone might worship, and whatever other claims to divine power someone might offer up, Jesus trumps them all. He is the son not just of some god, but of the Most High God.

The fact that there is a legion of demons, as they admit in verse 9, simply heightens the contrast. We knew already that the â€œimpure spiritâ€ was able to torment the man; now we know that it is many demons. It doesnâ€™t matter. Theyâ€™re still reduced to begging and pleading with him: verse 10 tells us that the manâ€”really, the spirits speaking through himâ€”â€œbegged Jesus again and again not to send them out of the area.â€

Again, the power curve: Jesusâ€™ authority isnâ€™t even in the same ballpark as anyone else in the storyâ€”not the demonized man, not the people who were unable to help him or even restrain him, not the silent disciples, and not even the multitude of demons. He exceeds them all.

Beat 2b: Jesusâ€™ focus â€“ 5:11â€“13

Jesusâ€™ power is only part of the story, though. As we come into vv. 11â€“13, we can see his focus as well. And that focus is healing a man in need. Read with me, starting in verse 11:

A large herd of pigs was feeding on the nearby hillside. The demons begged Jesus, â€œSend us among the pigs; allow us to go into them.â€ He gave them permission, and the impure spirits came out and went into the pigs. The herd, about two thousand in number, rushed down the steep bank into the lake and were drowned.

First, this confirms what we already know: they need Jesusâ€™ permission. He is in charge. But, second, it also tells us that between the man and the pigs, there wasnâ€™t a contest for Jesus. Not because he didnâ€™t care about pigs. We know from Colossians 1 that the eternal Son of Godâ€”who Mark is taking this whole book to tell us aboutâ€”is the agent of Godâ€™s creation of the whole universe; and his powerful word is the reason that the whole universe keeps existing, pigs included. Pigs were part of what he called a â€œgoodâ€ creation in Genesis 1. Speaking as a lover of bacon myself, Iâ€™m inclined to agree with Godâ€™s assessment: pigs are good.

But, and this is important: people are more important than pigs. You can find any number of modern commentators on this passage asking about the ethical implications of Jesusâ€™ letting the demons destroy the pigs along with themselves in this way. Neither Mark nor Luke or Matthew seem bothered by this point. Neither does Jesus. Pigs matter. Pigs are good. But they donâ€™t matter like people do. And while it is not clear from this passage why Jesus accepted the demonsâ€™ request, what is clear is that his mercy toward this manâ€”his compassion on himâ€”trumped any concern for the pigs. Jesusâ€™ focus was healing and saving people. Here, we see clearly that his powerful word is not just for creation, but also for salvation.

This tells us something about Jesusâ€™ power and authority. It is good power and authority. He is merciful. And it is so importantâ€”extraordinarily importantâ€”that the Son of the Most High God, the king bringing in his kingdom, be merciful. Because as Ephesians 2 tells us, before God intervenes in our lives, weâ€™re all like this man was. We start off dead in our sins, slaves to our lusts and every desire gone wrong and totally unchecked, in the domain of darkness, following the prince of the power of the air, the spirit now at work in the children of disobedience. The demons, in other words. And then Jesus steps in. As the rightful king, he has the power to free usâ€¦ and heâ€™s a merciful king, so he does free us. Thatâ€™s good news. Thatâ€™s gospel.

Beat 3: A fearful crowd â€“ 5:14â€“17

Of course, it doesnâ€™t always look like good news to everyone when Jesus shows up and starts healing people. Remember, Mark is showing us the truth of those parables from back in chapter 4. So we see here the good king who is bringing in his kingdomâ€”in secret now, but someday in glorious lightâ€”but we also see those different kinds of soil from the parable of the sower and the seed: some fruitful, some not fruitful.

Look at what happens in verses 14 through 17:

Those tending the pigs ran off and reported this in the town and countryside, and the people went out to see what had happened. When they came to Jesus, they saw the man who had been possessed by the legion of demons, sitting there, dressed and in his right mind; and they were afraid. Those who had seen it told the people what had happened to the demon-possessed manâ€”and told about the pigs as well. Then the people began to plead with Jesus to leave their region.

I can imagine being one of the herdsmen, seeing the pigs drowned by demons, and being frightenedâ€”and maybe they were. But thatâ€™s not what Mark says. Thatâ€™s not why these people were afraid. They were afraid because they saw this man who had been naked, clothed; who had been running and screaming, sitting calmly; who had been out of his mind, now in his right mind. That was what made them afraid.

Mark has created a sharp contrast here: between this scene and the one that preceded it, the calming of the storm.

  • In both scenes, we see Jesus confronting something far more powerful than ordinary humans can handle: in the first, a terrible storm; in the second, a legion of demons.
  • In both scenes, we see him exercise his powerful word for mercy: in the first, to save his disciples from the storm; in the second, to save this man from the demons who tormented him.
  • In both scenes, we see the tumult of a broken world, and then calm and peace after Jesus acts.
  • And in both scenes, we see people who are afraid after Jesus acts.

But there seems to be more than one way to be â€œafraidâ€ when you see the power of Godâ€™s Spirit on display in the person of Jesus Christ. You can be afraid and still want to be with him, like the disciples. Or you can be afraid like these people wereâ€”they wanted him to leave.

Clearly, one of these is better than the other. Far better to be with Jesus even if his power is more than you can handleâ€”even if you find that the Son of God is not at all safe. Because he is good.

Beat 4: An effective commission â€“ 5:18â€“20

But Mark wants to take us even further than the disciplesâ€™ example. He wants us to see that we do not need to be afraid. Because Jesusâ€™ power is expressed in mercy to his people. The disciples didnâ€™t really understand who Jesus was yet, didnâ€™t really grasp either his power or his mercy yet, but someone surprising in this story does: an unclean Gentile man who had been tortured by demons. The man Jesus healed. The one to whom he so very powerfully showed mercy. Look! Verse 18:

As Jesus was getting into the boat, the man who had been demon-possessed begged to go with him.

He begged! He is the third person to beg or plead in this story. The demons begged not to be destroyed yetâ€”and Jesus surprisingly showed them mercy in that. The people pleaded with Jesus to leaveâ€”and Jesus surprisingly showed them mercy in that. And hereâ€”at last!â€”someone begs for the right thing: to be with Jesus. The same phrase as when Jesus called the disciples to be with him. And Jesus surprisinglyâ€¦ shows mercy by saying no to him. Verses 19 and 20:

Jesus did not let him, but said, â€œGo home to your own people and tell them how much the Lord has done for you, and how he has had mercy on you.â€ So the man went away and began to tell in the Decapolis how much Jesus had done for him. And all the people were amazed.

â€œGo home to your own peopleâ€, verse 19 saysâ€”some translations say â€œto your friendsâ€â€”â€œand tell them how much the Lord has done for you, and how he has mercy on you.â€ Precisely because this man understood Jesus great power and his great mercy, he had somewhere to be that wasnâ€™t with Jesus yet. He knew how great Godâ€™s power was, and he knew how deep Godâ€™s mercy was. So Jesus gave him a commission, and it looks familiar: go tell the nations what God has done. The nations: this is a Gentile, not a Jew; he is in the Decapolis, Gentile country, not Jewish country. â€œGo tell them about Godâ€™s mercy,â€ Jesus says to him. Because the mercy of God is not just for the Jews. Jesus was not going to be a petty little messiah, king of a corner of Palestine. Godâ€™s mercy was for the healing of the nations. And here we see the first taste of that in Markâ€”because what happened? â€œâ€¦all the people were amazed.â€

Mark doesnâ€™t tell us here what came of this, what the fruit was. We donâ€™t know how many of those who were amazed were just apparently fruitful soil, where the seed sprung up and soon withered. But it is clear that there was at least one who was good soil. And if Jesusâ€™ ministry in the Decapolis in chapter 7 is any indication, it seems the Spirit may well have been using this manâ€™s seed-sowing to prepare a great harvest some day.

One more thing to see here: a detail, but not a little thing. Unlike the disciples, who hadnâ€™t gotten it yetâ€”this man proclaimed exactly what he should have. Notice, Jesus tells him to say what â€œthe Lordâ€ had done for him. From a Jew, including Jesus, that meant â€œYahweh,â€ the God of Israel. And in verse 20, â€œthe man went away and began to tellâ€¦ how much Jesus had done for him.â€ And rightly so. The mercy of Yahweh, the God of Israel, is the mercy of Jesus, the Son of the Most High Godâ€”the God over every pagan deity, over every demonic power, over every human heart, over all nations.

Summation

A few years ago, John Piper was preaching a missions sermon, and he started with Mark 5:19. You can see why. Itâ€™s the heart of the gospel. And Piper summed up the heart of the gospel this way:

God sent his Son into the world to save sinners from every nation so that they would glorify him for his mercy.

And thatâ€™s right. This whole narrative is a microcosm, a little picture, of the gospel, and of the right response to the gospel. Here we have a story of a Gentile manâ€”one of the nations, not a Jewâ€”who was literally enslaved by the powers of hell, set free by Jesus. But not just set free; set free and given a commission. Look there at verse 19 again: â€œGo home to your friends and tell them how much the Lord has done for you, and how he has had mercy on you.â€ That commission tells us what this story is about. And the center of that commission is the center of Markâ€™s gospel. And in fact, itâ€™s the center of the whole Bible. Itâ€™s the center of this great story we are all part of. Godâ€™s power, expressed in mercy, to save people from every nation through Jesus Christ.

Look how much he has done for us because of that mercy! He saves people like you and me, people from every nation who canâ€™t save themselves, and he invites them into his kingdom, and he gives them a mission.

Invitation

Which is to say, he gives us a mission. If you are a Christian in this roomâ€”if you have said to Jesus, â€œLet me be with youâ€â€”then he has said to you, â€œGo and tell your friends how much the Lord has done for you and how he has shown mercy to you.â€ Every one of us should want others to know how God has saved us. If you arenâ€™t doing that, I challenge you: tell the people around you! Tell your friends, your coworkers, your family members. If thatâ€™s hard for youâ€”and I understand; it can beâ€”then think back on your salvation. Think about how God has shown mercy to you. Pray for the Spirit to stir you up, to deepen your love for him and your joy in what he has done, so that your telling others isnâ€™t out of guilt, but out of excitement. Thatâ€™s a prayer he delights to answer.

And friend, if you are in this room and you are not in the kingdom? We have a good king, who offers you a pardon for your rebellion. You can be a citizen with us; we were all rebels, too. Come to him. Ask to be with him. Join us as we follow him. He has shown us mercy; he will show you mercy, too. All you have to do is surrender. Lay down your weapons. Ask for mercy. And call him Lord. If thatâ€™s you, please: let us walk with you. Come talk with us before you leave.

Letâ€™s pray. Letâ€™s pray to our powerful, merciful God.
